When wind-spirit is awake it storms; asleep, it is calm.

content:
Why days shorten in autumn: the real sun sets very early
because the red cockscomb plant, used to kill his brother sun with, grows to
its full height during this time.

child: Why the sea is salt: because of wrecked salt ship.
Why the sea is salt: magic salt mill.

Stolen by sea-captain, who takes it aboard and orders it

Eberhard FFC CXX 108.

Why the sea is salt: heavy rain showers on ashes of wood burnt
by primeval fire.

Formerly men plowed and cattle were their masters.

Bees pray for sting: punishment, first sting suicidal.

(Cf. †A2346.1.)--Dh IV
266; Wienert FFC LVI 77 (ET 434), 110 (ST 216); Halm Aesop No. 287.

Beetle makes immoderate request; ant moderate: inverse
awards.

Creator hears wishes of animals. Beetle wants strong, noble appearance. Ant is
modest. Beetle punished by being made to creep on ground. Ant is given own
castle. (Cf. †A2441.3.1.) Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI 92 No. 97.
Griffin disdains to go on ark; drowned: hence extinct.
Animals ask for goddess‘s perfume: punishment, bad odor.
Birds who aspire to blackbird’s coat punished.

Peacock given ugly feet so as to prevent too great
arrogance.

Dog‘s embassy to Zeus chased forth; dogs seek ambassador:
why dogs sniff each other under leg.
Ants ask God to give them wings: wind blows them away.
Raven attempts to imitate dove: punished with awkward gait.

Donkeys ask immediate reward from God: eat their own
excrements.

content: Jewish: Neuman; Achawoi: Alexander Lat. Am. 270.
Wild animals lose their ferocity through fear of Behemoth.
All qualities of animals appear with their creation.

child:
Dog rescues cow‘s teats from fire: origin of his black
muzzle.

(Cf. †A2335.4.3.)--*Dh III 72ff., 500--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 10 No. 48,
XXXIII 53 No. 48; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 143 No. 27.

Dog lets devil into church to steal: rewarded with
dog-skin.
Owl will not betray curate: therefore may live in steeple.
Fly steals fire from spider: may eat everywhere.

Spider brings fire from
hell. Fly steals it from him on the way. (Cf. †A2545.1.)--Livonian: Loorits FFC
LXVI 93 No. 101.

Cuckoo delivers other birds from their cruel king: they
agree to hatch out cuckoo’s young.
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3137; Legends Nos. 253ff.

Bird has red spot on its tail as reward for having moved
woman‘s organ to its present position.

content:
Animal characteristics from dropping ancient animal from
air.
child: Swallow thrown on his tail: cause of split tail.

(Cf. †A2378.5.1.)--Dh II
126, III 419.--Aarne FFC VII 16 No. 85; Flemish: DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 87 No. 85.
Ant thrown from heaven: hence narrow waist.

God decides dispute between ant and spider in spider‘s favor. (Cf.
†A2355.1.2.)--Finnish: Aarne FFC VII 22 No. 124, XXXIII 55 No. 124; Esthonian:
Aarne FFC XXV 149 No. 66; Flemish: DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 89 No. 124; Lithuanian:
Balys Index No. 3200, Legends Nos 291--94; India: Thompson-Balys.

Unicorn thrown from ark and drowned: hence no longer
exists.
Crab thrown to ground: breaks into small pieces.
Hence crabs are small. India: Thompson-Balys.
Tortoise hurled on rock: half falls on land, half in water.

Therefore amphibious. African (Nigeria): Herskovits JAFL
XLIV 448ff.
Tortoise dropped by eagle: hence cracks in his shell.

Bat falls from high perch due to extreme heat of sun’s
rays, breaks bones, etc.

Hence peculiar
feet and nose. India: Thompson-Balys.

Thrush‘s hospitality to peacock rewarded by being given
motley coat of feathers.
Cat helps man build house: may occupy chimney corner.

Bird carries deity (his daughter) home from land of skulls:
given brilliant plumage.

Mouse gathers rice for man: may eat a little of his rice
daily.
Pike helps Christ cross stream: made king of fishes.

Dog guards master’s life and wealth: may eat before other
animals.

Tortoise given hard shell when it ferries rice-goddess
across stream.

Ravens show Adam how to bury dead: are born with white
feathers.
Chameleon saves hero’s life: may change color.
Hedgehog’s skin reward for good deed.

content: Animal characteristics reward for pious act.
child: Animals blessed for honoring infant Jesus.

(Cf. †A2231.4,
†A2356.2.7, †A2381.1.)--Dh II 15f., 195ff.; Flemish: DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 86 No.
58c (cross on back of ass).--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 13 No. 67 (hog has good
flesh); French: Sébillot France III 256.
Animals blessed for good services at crucifixion.

They look like nails and prevent more nails being driven.
They may eat at the king’s table. (Cf. †A2545.1.) Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 150 No. 68 (cf.
No. 69).

Blood from cross on robin redbreast: He helps Jesus;
rewarded with red breast.
Blood of scourged Christ on certain spiders.

Swallows lift Christ‘s crown of thorns from his brow: why
their nests are not destroyed.

Swallows put on mourning at crucifixion: have never taken
it off.

Crossbill, attempting to draw thorn from the crown of
thorns, twists bill in the attempt.

Markings on animals as recollections of Christ’s life and
sufferings.
Ant collects incense and myrrh for Christ: grows thin in middle.
Animal blessed for helping holy fugitive.

(Cf. †A2231.7.1.)--Dh II
53ff.--Irish: Beal XXI 306; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI 93 No. 100.

Ox helps patriarch who in joy kisses him on the lips: hence
no hair on ox’s lips.

Jewish: bin Gorion
Born Judas III 118, 304, *Neuman.
Animal blessed for obedience to deity.
Bird coloring as reward for obedience to deity.

Dove returns to ark in obedience to Noah: receives sheen of
raven.

Squirrel‘s markings and immunity from falling as reward by
deity.

Why sheep walk with bowed heads: they have remained so
after having bowed to God.
Sheep helpful to the Lord: get wool.

Deity rewards animal for bringing him water: cause of
present characteristics.

content:
Animal characteristics from transformation of implement (or
other object).
child:
Horse originally had eyes on feet: put out and became
eyelike marks.
Pegs driven into backs of baboons become tails.
Serpent steals from God‘s coat a stick for his back.

content: Animal characteristics: stolen from another animal.
Animal characteristics from transformation of animal.
child:
Shepherd transformed to bird still calls sheep: explanation
of bird cries.

Usually told of hoopoe and bittern. (Cf. †A1952, †A1965.2, †A2275.3,
†A2425, †A2426.2.3, †A2426.2.4.)--*Dh III 392--396; BP III 285 (Gr. No.
173).--Japanese: Ikeda; Chinese: Eberhard FFC CXX 123 No. 83, 127.

Spider transformed for greediness: now occupies dark
corners.

Catfish transformed from woman still carries women‘s tatoo
marks.

Catfish transformed from children still carry marks of
children’s knife holder.
Woodpecker transformed from stingy woman: therefore stingy.
Weeping man turned into owl; still bewails sorrows.

Snipe messenger for warriors because he was a messenger
when a man.

content: Animal characteristics: borrowing and not returning.

Animal borrows a member
(or quality) from another and refuses to return it. (Cf. †A2242, †A2313.3,
†A2345.1, †A2351.3, †A2375.2.1, †A2421.4, †A2435.4.1.)--*Dh III 130
ff.--Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 268ff.; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Owl‘s wings borrowed from rat (or other animal).
Cuckoo borrows food from other birds.

Each has one eye. Nightingale borrow’s blindworm‘s and will not return it.
(Cf. †A2332.6.1.)--*Type 234; *Dh III 136ff.; *Köhler-Bolte I 72.--Finnish:
Aarne FFC XXXIII 55 No. 110** (frog in place of nightingale).--Japanese: Ikeda;
English: Shakespeare Romeo and Juliet III v. 31.

When coney’s tail is not returned, he goes in shame to live among rocks. (Cf.
†A2378.1.5, †A2433.3.5.)--Ila (Rhodesia): Smith and Dale 357 No. 10.

Boy borrows python‘s hands and feet: hence python lacks
them.
Beaver borrows muskrat‘s tail and never gives it back.
Menomini: Skinner and Satterlee PaAM XIII 405.
Monkey borrows tail from deer and refuses to return it.

content:
Animal characteristics: obtaining for feast and not
returning.

Animal characteristics: lending and refusing to receive
back.
child:
Spider hands box to ant and refuses to take it back: hence
ants carry huge loads.

Gold Coast: Barker
and Sinclair 66 No. 9.

content:
Animal characteristics from squeezing or stretching ancient
animal.
child: Ancient animal squeezed: hence small size.

(Cf. †A2302.)--Dh III
2--7 (hazel-grouse, squirrel, eagle, wolf, snake‘s
head.)
Animal pressed: hence facial or bodily marks.

(Cf. †A2230.1.)--Dh III
5, 6.--N. Am. Indian: *Thompson Tales 300 n. 99; Australian: Dixon 290
(wombat).
Tortoise pressed into earth: hence humpy back.

Baboon pressed on hot, flat rock: hence bald place on his
back.
(Cf. †A2317.10.)--Africa (Hottentot): Bleek 39 No. 19; Indonesian: De Vries’s list No. 74.
Why lobster is shallow: insulted cattle step on it.

Mole struck on head in attempt to steal fire: hence his
flat head.
S. Am. Indian (Toba): Métraux MAFLS XL 109.
Fish struck by coconut: hence flat tail.

Frightened rabbit puts head in charred tree: hence black
ears.

Frightened animals scatter: cause of present habitat of
each.

content: Enmity between animals from original quarrel.
child: Cat loses dog’s certificate: enmity between cats and dogs.

Dog is given a certificate of nobility. Through cat‘s carelessness it is
lost. (Cf. †A2275.5, †A2494.1.2.) *Type 200.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 11 No.
53; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 143 No. 30; Livonian: Loorits FFC LXVI 88 No. 61;
Flemish: DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 85 No. 53.

Cat garbles message from man to tiger: enmity between man
and tiger.
Quarrel of dog and cat about which was higher caste.
Squirrel steals dog’s needle: enmity between them.

Why cat and dog fight: dog ate up cat‘s part in master’s
reward.

content: Present habitat of animals result of ancient quarrel.

Two animals learn songs together--one successfully, the
other unsuccessfully.

Origin of animal characteristics: animal persuaded into
self-injury.
child: Animal persuaded to amputate limb: therefore lacks it.

Bustard persuaded to kill all but two children: has but two
eggs.

Worm, thinking that world is coming to end, blinds self so
as not to see calamity.
Elephant tricked into eating own testicles.

Has them inside. (Cf.
†A2365.1.1.)--Ila (Rhodesia): Smith and Dale 361 No. 14.

Coyote persuaded to break leg: therefore has thin right
leg.
Jackal persuades hyena to jump and break foot.

Latter has short left
hind foot. (Cf. †A2375.2.5.)--Hottentot: Bleek 14 No. 14.
Creation interrupted since God must go to a fire.

Animal characteristics because creator had not enough time
to finish what he began.
S. Am. Indian (Caingang): Métraux BBAE CXLIII (1) 474.

Creation of hog incomplete since God has to go to a fire:
cause of hog‘s round snout.

Animal characteristics result of contest between God and
devil.

God makes white fish,
devil a pike to eat it up; God a worm, devil a frog to eat it, etc. (Cf.
†A1751.)--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 20 No. 115; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 149 No.
63.
Devil gives horse four eyes; God reduces them to two.
Devil’s cows one-horned; God makes them two-horned.
God changes color (tails) of devil‘s cows.

Devil makes all animals
of same color (or all tailless). When God makes them of different colors (or
with tails) devil no longer recognizes them. (Cf. †A2378.1.)--Esthonian: Aarne
FFC XXV 146 No. 47; Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3083, Legends Nos. 134--137.
Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence short snouts.

Jesus drives evil spirits into hogs: hence “toes” on back
of foreleg.

Animals refuse to help dig well (make road) and are
punished.

Animals refuse to help dig well: may not drink from river
or spring.
Snake refuses to help make road: dies on road.
Shrew refuses to help make road: dies on road.

(Cf. †A2468.1.)--Dh III
323f.; cf. Type 55.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 15 No. 80; Lithuanian: Balys Index
No. 3098, Legends Nos. 183--191.
Sloth refuses to help make road: may not look upon sun.
Dog will not help build house: must remain out of doors.

Too cold for hare (dog) to build house in winter, not
necessary in summer: must go without house.

Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 72*, Legends No. 214; Finnish: Aarne Index No. 72*;
Russian: Andrejev No. 72**.
Owl as watchman goes to sleep: does not see by day.

He is placed as watchman
of wren who is imprisoned in a mousehole. (Cf. †A2332.6.6.)--Type 221; *Dh IV
172ff.

Grasshopper builds no house for winter; ant strikes him
blind: therefore born blind.
Bird neglects to build nest: goes without.

content: Animal characteristics learned from another animal.
child: Thrush teaches dove to build nest.

(Cf. †A2431.3.1.)--*Type
236; Dh III 191ff.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 17 No. 93; Flemish: DeMeyer FFC
XXXVII 88 No. 93.

Sparrow taught to sing by lark but not sufficiently: where
sparrow got voice.

content: Animal habit a reminiscence of former experience.
child:
Animal cries a lament for person lost when animal was
transformed.
Animal cries a lament over animal’s transformation.
Animal cries reminiscent of former life as man.

The ancient animal cries
out in difficulty. The present animal has the same cry. (Cf. †A2426.1.1,
†A2426.4.1.)--India: Thompson-Balys; Ibo (Nigeria): Basden 139; Angola:
Chatelain 217 No. 38.
Green pigeon cheated out of its chick: is always mourning.
Animal‘s seeking attitude from ancient loss.

The ancient animal loses
something. Its descendants are forever seeking for the lost object. This
explains the characteristic bearing of certain animals. (Cf. †A2471.)
Hog loses pancake in mud: still seeks it.

Hawk (vulture) loses grandmother: still hovers and seeks
her.

Bat brought money, bush
put on clothes, and diver brought leather. All shipwrecked. Diver is looking
for his leather. Bush looks for his clothers and holds fast to all passers-by.
Bat is abroad only at night to escape creditors. (Cf. †A2471.4, †A2491.1.)--*Dh
IV 273f; *BP I 137. (Gr. No. 18).--Wienert FFC LVI 35; Halm Aesop No. 306.

He loses his magic ring
in the sea. They are sent by God to get it. This is why they go up and down in
the sea. (Cf. †A2444.2.)--Dh I 331; Jewish: Neuman.

Dog loses his patent right; seeks it: why dogs look at one
another under the tail.

Son accidentally kills father, who returns to life as
cuckoo and tells people when to sow grain.
Hare punished for perjury: eyes deep in head.

Fly punished for failing to answer question: is speechless,
buzzes and associates with foul things.
Ass betrays deity’s secret: hence his ugly bray.
Owl reveals deity’s secret: power of speech removed.
Ass has cross on shoulders from being struck by Balaam.

Crocodile is punished for trying to attack man he is
carrying: has only half tongue.

Animal punished for hardheadedness (frog toothless, mole
sightless).

Why mouse is crushed whenever she crosses a road:
elephant‘s curse.

Why elephant hurts himself when running through the grass:
mouse’s curse.

Rabbit (frog) eats seed-grain from fields: nose closed
during sowing season.

(Cf. †A2335.2.4.)--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 21 No. 119;
Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 290.
Ring-dove eats man‘s grain: man may kill him.

Similarly francolin and guinea fowl. Ila (Rhodesia): Smith
and Dale 351 No. 6.
Fish eat other fish: guilty must swim deep.

Diver eats nests of small birds: must not nest away from
water.

content:
Animal characteristics: accidental action of ancient
animal.
child: Lynx views country from mountainside: cause of his squint.
Wolf falls out of nest: cause of straight back.
Why some whales die on land: first whale did so.

Sent after fire, he finds but a little which he tries to
revive by hard blowing.--Fang: Nassau 234 No. 3.

Spider carries large stone on head and drops it: hence
spiders under stones.
Birds cling to sky in flood: cause of tail colors.
Lizard dips head in palm-oil: cause of red head.
Lizard swallows fish bone: hence head bobs up and down.
Tortoise left out in rain: hard shell develops.

How rattlesnake became harmful: earthworm feeds him chili
pepper.
S. Am. Indian (Toba): Métraux MAFLS XL 68.

Buffalo helps tiger quench fire: white mark left on
buffalo‘s neck where tiger held on while being ducked in water.
Stag defeated by snail vomits his gall-bladder.

Rat defecates on octopus’s head: origin of tubercles on
head.

Goddess scatters pubic hairs on fish: why he has so many
bones.
Buffalo and cow exchange hides: hence bad fitting hides.
Snake and turtle exchange head for fangs.

Explains snake‘s fangs and snake-like head of turtle. (Cf. †A2320.2, A
2345.5.)--Australian: Dixon 291.
Rhinoceros exchanges his red hide for hippopotamus’s black.

Dove and magpie exchange eggs--dove‘s seven for magpie’s
two: why dove has two eggs.
Toad trades his tail for mole‘s eyes.

content: Appearance of animal from marking or painting.
child:
Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3158; N. Am. Indian: *Boas
RBAE XXXI 664, (Tahltan): Teit JAFL XXXII 208 No. 1 (10), (Cherokee): Alexander
N. Am. 66 (robin redbreast).
Chipmunk‘s back scratched: hence his stripes.

As he is trying to
escape, bear catches him with his claws and marks him permanently. (Cf.
†A2413.2.)--Seneca: Curtin-Hewitt RBAE XXXII 111 No. 13, 422 No. 78, Curtin
Seneca 437, 505.
Marks on certain fish from fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from St. Peter’s fingerprints.
Marks on certain fish from devil‘s fingerprints.

content: Animal characteristics: members bitten or cut off.
child: Bear fishes through ice with tail: hence lacks tail.

(Cf. †A2378.2.4.)--*Type
2; Dh III 49.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 14 No. 78; Esthonian: Aarne FFC XXV 146
No. 42; Flemish: DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 86 No. 78; Japanese: Ikeda.
Devil pulls off goats’ tails: hence lack tails.
Moon splits hare‘s lip with hatchet: hence hare-lip.

Bush-rat bites off tortoise’s tail: hence tortoise‘s short
tail.
Hawk’s tail cut in two by sword as he is being transformed.

Cause of his forked
tail. (Cf. †A2378.5.2.)--Dh III 54.
God as falcon has tail cut off: hence falcon‘s short tail.

Formerly animals have ears like elephant’s: hare bites them
off.

content:
Animal characteristics from throwing members at ancient
animal.
child: Stick (leaf) thrown at animal‘s rump: hence tails.

(Cf.
†A2378.3.3.)--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 14 No. 77 (wolf).--Banks Is.: Dixon 144
(rat).
Hare runs away at creation; almost loses tail.

When, as the most timid
of all beasts, he runs away, God throws a tail at him from a pile of tails.
(Cf. †A2378.4.1.)--Dh III 185.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 13 No. 72; Flemish:
DeMeyer FFC XXXVII 86 No. 72.
Bowl placed on turtle’s back: hence his shell.

Red fruit thrown at rail‘s (bird’s) head: hence red lump on
head.
Fox struck with churn-dash: hence white tail.

(Cf. †A2378.8.1.)--Cf.
Type 3.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 15 No. 79; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 146 No. 43.

God throws diver‘s feet after him; hence his feet reach
backward.
(Cf. †A2371.2.9.) Dh III 46.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 18 No. 103.

content:
Animal characteristics: imitation of other animal or
object.
child: Nightingale hears boy call oxen: learns her song.
Cricket hears water hiss on hot iron: learns his song.
Garden warbler hears smith beat iron: learns his song.
Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 20 No. 110, XXXIII 55 No. 110.

content:
(Cf. †A2221, †A2311.8,
†A2422.2, †A2302.2, †A2355.1.2, †A2542.1.)--Dh II 252f. (fish).--Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 17 No. 97, XXXIII 54 No. 97
(hazelcock).
child:
Animal characteristics: punishment for discourteous answer
to God (saint).
Discourteous answer: why cow (horse) is always eating.

When God (Peter) wants to use the cow (horse) the excuse
is made that she (he) is eating. Curse: “May you always be eating!” (Cf. †A2472.1,
†A2478.)--Dh II 93; *Fb “hest” IV
211b.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 11 No. 59 (horse); ibid. 12 No. 62 (cow);
Esthonian: Aarne FFC XXV 143 No. 32 (horse); Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 3094,
Legends Nos. 163--175.
Discourteous answer: why crab has eyes behind.

(Cf.
†A2332.4.1.)--Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV 151 No. 74; Lithuanian: Balys Index No.
3178, Legends Nos. 273--281.

Zeus celebrates a wedding and invites the animals.
Tortoise is late. Why? “I like my house.” “May you bear your house always.” (Cf. †A2312.1.)--Dh IV
275f.--Wienert FFC LVI 76 (ET 424), 139 (ST 443); Halm Aesop No. 154.

Animal characteristics: punishment for hostility at
crucifixion.

Crane will not weep at crucifixion: must suffer thirst in
August and break bills.

Is the only bird who will not weep. (Cf. †A2234.1,
†A2435.4.2.)--Köhler-Bolte I 3.
Swallows torment Christ on cross: lose voice.
Animal characteristics: punishment for working on holy day.
Cuckoo builds nest on Annunciation Day: has no nest.
Bees work on Sabbath: may not get honey from red clover.
Frog fails to honor infant Jesus: loses tail.
Spider vies with Virgin Mary in spinning: cursed.

Spider steals thread from Christ: has thread in back of
body.

(Cf. †A2356.2.8.)--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 22 No. 123; Estonian: Aarne FFC XXV
149 No. 65.
Animal harmful to holy person cursed.
Animal cursed for betraying holy fugitive.

(Cf. †A2221.5.)--Dh II
51ff.; Child V 491 s.v. “partridge”; Ireland:
Baughman.

Beetle cursed for betraying Holy Family on way to Egypt;
beetle now has its eyes always on the ground.

Animal cursed for refusing to carry holy fugitive across
stream.

Tortoise cursed for going under water while ferrying
rice-goddess: people will be able to kill it with iron-made spears.

Toad refuses to weep over its dead children: dries up when
dead.
Fish in deluge deride God: are flattened with blow.

They mock God for his
powerlessness over them. (Cf. †A2213, †A2305.1, †A2354.1.)--Dh I 290.
Crab beats deity‘s forbidden drum: eyes lift out of body.
Beetle demands return of gold from God: must hum.

In his overweening pride
he hits fence and ever afterward has hummed. (Cf. †A2426.3.1.)--Dh. III
376.--Finnish: Aarne FFC VIII 22 No. 121.

Buffaloes fail to come at god’s leavetaking: now are killed
by tigers.

Loris refuse to look at sun who comes out when they are
dancing: hence never looks at sun.
Animal has color spilled on him: cause of his color.
Cow swallows book; cause of maniplies in stomach.
Only one serpent had sting: fed poison to the rest.

content: Animal characteristics from burning or singeing.
child: Raven caught in smoke-hole: hence is black.

(Cf. †A2411.2.1.5.)--Dh
III 72, 77ff.--N. A. Indian: *Boas RBAE XXXI 652, (Tahltan): Teit JAFL XXXII
203 No. 1 (3).

Animal scorches self while putting out fire in land of fire,
woe and darkness.
Jackal carries sun in bag on back; burns his back black.
Animal who steals fire scorched: cause of his color.

Coyote burnt when hay is set afire: hence yellow patch
behind his ears.

Salinan: Mason U. Cal.
XIV 88, cf. 107.
Robin steals fire, has breast scorched.

Raven singes feet on hot stones: why its wings clap when it
flies.
Rabbit burns self under chin when he steals an ember.

S. Am. Indian (Toba):
Métraux MAFLS XL 109.
Eel burned by torch: hence red eyes.

content:
Animal characteristics caused by animal‘s lateness at
distribution of qualities.

(Cf. †A2378.2.5.)--Dh III 182ff.--India: Thompson-Balys; Mpongwe:
Nassau No. 11 (hog lacks horns); Gold Coast: Barker and Sinclair 145 No. 28
(leopard cannot catch game that passes him on right side); Congo: Weeks 213 No.
9 (water snake lacks poison): Zulu: Callaway 355 (hydrax lacks tail); Ila
(Rhodesia): Smith and Dale 368 No. 19 (zebra lacks horns); Marshall Islands:
Davenport 222.

child:
Raven does not return to Noah: must suffer thirst and break
bill.

(Cf. †A2231.2.1, †A2411.2.1.5, †A2435.4.3.)--Variant: he is cursed to be black
or to eat carrion. *Köhler-Bolte I 3; Dh I 284; Irish myth: Cross.

Raven does not return to ark in obedience to Noah: black
color is resulting punishment.
Animals eat deity’s forbidden fruit: punished.
Lemur looks where forbidden: has big eyes.

Hare weeps for mother when forbidden: moon hits him and
cleaves lip.
Animal reveals mistress’s adultery: punished by master.

(Cf. †A2411.2.1.5,
†A2422.1.1.).--Greek: Fox 280 (raven becomes black).--Zuñi: Handy JAFL XXXI 464
No. 17 (dog loses power of speech).

content:
Animal characteristics: punishment for planning man’s
downfall.
child: What creature has sweetest blood: gnat‘s tongue torn out.

Assembly to decide who
has the sweetest blood so that it may be the food for the serpent. Gnat
discovers that man has the sweetest blood. Rather than let him tell this
secret, swallow tears out his tongue. Gnat can only buzz. (Cf. †A2344.2,
†A2426.3.2.)--Dh I 281, 332ff.; Circassian: Nicolaides and Carnoy RTP I 80;
Lithuanian: Balys Legends No. 192.

Animal characteristics: punishment for carrying devil into
paradise.
Snake carries devil into paradise: loses feet.

Peacock has snake carry devil into paradise: cursed with
ugly voice and feet.

Origin of insects: monstrous births from brother-sister

content:
Such a world is assumed before the real creation of the universe.

motif †A31, Creator‘s
grandmother.--Jewish: *Neuman.--Samoa: Dixon 18f.; Hawaii: Beckwith Myth 45.
